intro: Heckeria subpeltata, commonly known as the Florida hecker, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its basal rosette of narrow, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically blue or violet in color. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands and swampy areas. Heckeria subpeltata is an important species for ecological studies due to its unique adaptations to wetland environments.
